section.title: Adjectives and adverbs
section.sectiontitle: Adjectives are used to describe nouns. They usually come directly before the noun.
section.text2: There is a school in the village.
section.text2a: There is a small school in the village.
section.sectiontitle2: Adverbs (and adverbial phrases) are used to modify verbs, adjectives and other adverbs.

section.title: Adjectives and adverbs
section.sectiontitle: Connecting adverbs, (e.g. nevertheless, then, however, besides) which join a clause to what came before, can come at the beginning of a sentence.
section.text1: We were impressed by your CV.
section.text1a: Nevertheless, we are unable to offer you the post.
section.text2: We applied for the tickets well in advance.
section.sectiontitle2: If the adverb is not the main focus of the message we can put time adverbs (e.g. tomorrow, last year, recently, yesterday) at the beginning of the sentence.
section.text3: I've noticed he's been behaving strangely.
section.text3a: Recently I've noticed he's been behaving strangely.
section.text4a: Last year I passed my driving test.

section.title: Adjectives and adverbs
section.sectiontitle: Adverbs of certainty and completeness (e.g. probably, nearly) and adverbs of indefinite frequency (e.g. often, sometimes) can come in the middle of a sentence, before the main verb.
section.text1a: I think the witness probably lied to the jury.
section.text2a: At this time of year it often rains in the afternoons.
section.sectiontitle2: Adverbs of comment (e.g. stupidly, ignorantly, wildly, brilliantly) can come in the middle of a sentence.
section.text3a: The young doctor stupidly forgot to take the patient's temperature.
section.text4a: He arrogantly told us he always got the best results.

section.title: Adjectives and adverbs
section.sectiontitle: Adverbs of manner (e.g. slowly, rudely, with interest, carefully, in a friendly way) can come at the end of a sentence.
section.text1a: He smiled at her in a friendly way.
section.sectiontitle2: But if the adverb of manner is not the main focus of the message it usually comes in the middle of the sentence, before the main verb.
section.text3: He opened the box with a sense of mounting curiosity.
section.text3a: He slowly opened the box with a sense of mounting curiosity.
section.text4: She got up and went to answer the door.
section.text4a: She reluctantly got up and went to answer the door.

section.title: Adjectives and adverbs
section.sectiontitle: Adverbs of place (e.g. upstairs, in the corner, throughout the world, over there) can come at the end of a sentence.
section.text1a: I think I left my keys over there.
section.sectiontitle2: Adverbs of time (e.g. this morning, a while ago, all the time) can also come at the end of a sentence if they are the main focus of the message.
section.text4: I can't remember exactly when I sent John the letter.
section.text4a: I sent John that letter a while ago.

section.title: Adjectives and adverbs
section.sectiontitle: Many adverbs end in -ly, but some words ending in -ly are adjectives not adverbs, e.g. friendly, lively, lonely, lovely, silly, ugly, unlikely, deadly.
section.text1a: My teacher is really kind and friendly.
section.text2a: Life in a big city can be lonely.
section.sectiontitle2: There are also many adverbs which do not end in -ly. Some common ones are late, fast, fine, hard, high and well.
section.text3a: He was in a hurry so he drove fast.
section.text4a: She felt fine despite her recent accident.

section.title: Adjectives and adverbs
section.sectiontitle: Sometimes the adjective and adverb have the same form. Some common ones are fast, hard, fine, early and daily.
section.text1a: He's worked really hard for his exam.
section.text2a: This chair is too hard to sit on all day.
